Japonsko kulturno priznanje prvič v roke ustvarjalcu videoiger

06 Nov 2019, 12:16

Japonska s kulturnim priznanjem vsako leto nagradi osebo, ki ima posebne zasluge na področju akademije, znanosti, umetnosti in športa. In čeprav je priznanje v preteklih letih že romalo v roke ustvarjalcem stripov manga ter animiranih filmov, je bila letos pozornost prvič doslej usmerjena v svet videoiger.
Priznanje je tokrat namreč končno prejel legendarni japonski ustvarjalec videoiger, Šigeru Mijamoto, avtor ikoničnih franšiz, kot so: Super Mario, Donkey Kong, The Legend of Zelda, Star Fox in F-Zero. Mijamoto je ob tej priložnosti povedal, da je hvaležen za pozornost, ki so je s podelitvijo priznanja prejele videoigre in da gre obenem za delovni proces, v katerem brez pomoči soustvarjalcev ne moreš narediti ničesar.
66-letni Mijamoto, ki je svojo poklicno pot pričel leta 1977 v Nintendu, zatrjuje, da se še ne namerava upokojiti, saj želi še lep čas risati nasmehe ne obraze ljubiteljev videoiger. Poleg njega pa so priznanje letos prejeli tudi kemijski nobelovec Akira Jošino, filmski režiser Nobuhiko Obajaši, ilustratorka mang Moto Hagio in kabuki igralec Bando Tamasaburo.
text:
For the first time, Japanese cultural recognition is in the hands of the video game creator

06 Nov 2019, 12:16

With cultural recognition, Japan annually awards a person with special merit in academia, science, arts and sports. And although recognition has been a pilgrimage to the makers of manga comics and animated films over the years, this year, for the first time, the focus has been on the video game world.
This recognition was finally awarded to legendary Japanese video game maker Shigeru Miyamoto, author of iconic franchises such as Super Mario, Donkey Kong, The Legend of Zelda, Star Fox and F-Zero. Mijamoto said on this occasion that he is grateful for the attention that video games have received with the award, and that it is also a work process in which you cannot do anything without the help of co-creators.
Mijamoto, 66, who began his career in Nintendo in 1977, says he has no plans to retire yet, since he wants to have a good time drawing the smiles and faces of video game enthusiasts. Apart from him, this year's award went to Chemical Nobel Prize winner Akira Jošino, film director Nobuhiko Obajaši, manga illustrator Moto Hagio and kabuki actor Bando Tamasaburo.
